3.verse: and said, “Unless you turn to God from your sins and become as little children, you will never get into the Kingdom of Heaven.

4.verse: Therefore anyone who humbles himself as this little child is the greatest in the Kingdom of Heaven.

5.verse: And any of you who welcomes a little child like this because you are mine is welcoming me and caring for me.

6.verse: But if any of you causes one of these little ones who trusts in me to lose his faith, it would be better for you to have a rock tied to your neck and be thrown into the sea.

7.verse: “Woe upon the world for all its evils. Temptation to do wrong is inevitable, but woe to the man who does the tempting.

8.verse: So if your hand or foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. Better to enter heaven crippled than to be in hell with both of your hands and feet.

9.verse: And if your eye causes you to sin, gouge it out and throw it away. Better to enter heaven with one eye than to be in hell with two.

10.verse: “Beware that you don’t look down upon a single one of these little children. For I tell you that in heaven their angels have constant access to my Father.

11.verse: And I, the Messiah, came to save the lost.

12.verse: “If a man has a hundred sheep, and one wanders away and is lost, what will he do? Won’t he leave the ninety-nine others and go out into the hills to search for the lost one?

13.verse: And if he finds it, he will rejoice over it more than over the ninety-nine others safe at home!

14.verse: Just so, it is not my Father’s will that even one of these little ones should perish.

15.verse: “If a brother sins against you, go to him privately and confront him with his fault. If he listens and confesses it, you have won back a brother.

16.verse: But if not, then take one or two others with you and go back to him again, proving everything you say by these witnesses.

17.verse: If he still refuses to listen, then take your case to the church, and if the church’s verdict favors you, but he won’t accept it, then the church should excommunicate him.

18.verse: And I tell you this—whatever you bind on earth is bound in heaven, and whatever you free on earth will be freed in heaven.

19.verse: “I also tell you this—if two of you agree down here on earth concerning anything you ask for, my Father in heaven will do it for you.

20.verse: For where two or three gather together because they are mine, I will be right there among them.”

21.verse: Then Peter came to him and asked, “Sir, how often should I forgive a brother who sins against me? Seven times?”

22.verse: “No!” Jesus replied, “seventy times seven!

23.verse: “The Kingdom of Heaven can be compared to a king who decided to bring his accounts up to date.

24.verse: In the process, one of his debtors was brought in who owed him $10 million!

25.verse: He couldn’t pay, so the king ordered him sold for the debt, also his wife and children and everything he had.

26.verse: “But the man fell down before the king, his face in the dust, and said, ‘Oh, sir, be patient with me and I will pay it all.’

27.verse: “Then the king was filled with pity for him and released him and forgave his debt.

28.verse: “But when the man left the king, he went to a man who owed him $2,000 and grabbed him by the throat and demanded instant payment.

29.verse: “The man fell down before him and begged him to give him a little time. ‘Be patient and I will pay it,’ he pled.

30.verse: “But his creditor wouldn’t wait. He had the man arrested and jailed until the debt would be paid in full.

31.verse: “Then the man’s friends went to the king and told him what had happened.

32.verse: And the king called before him the man he had forgiven and said, ‘You evil-hearted wretch! Here I forgave you all that tremendous debt, just because you asked me to—

33.verse: shouldn’t you have mercy on others, just as I had mercy on you?’

34.verse: “Then the angry king sent the man to the torture chamber until he had paid every last penny due.

35.verse: So shall my heavenly Father do to you if you refuse to truly forgive your brothers.”

1.verse: After Jesus had finished this address, he left Galilee and circled back to Judea from across the Jordan River.

2.verse: Vast crowds followed him, and he healed their sick.

3.verse: Some Pharisees came to interview him and tried to trap him into saying something that would ruin him. “Do you permit divorce?” they asked.

4.verse: “Don’t you read the Scriptures?” he replied. “In them it is written that at the beginning God created man and woman,

5.verse: and that a man should leave his father and mother, and be forever united to his wife. The two shall become one—no longer two, but one! And no man may divorce what God has joined together.”

6.verse: and that a man should leave his father and mother, and be forever united to his wife. The two shall become one—no longer two, but one! And no man may divorce what God has joined together.”

7.verse: “Then, why,” they asked, “did Moses say a man may divorce his wife by merely writing her a letter of dismissal?”

8.verse: Jesus replied, “Moses did that in recognition of your hard and evil hearts, but it was not what God had originally intended.

9.verse: And I tell you this, that anyone who divorces his wife, except for fornication, and marries another, commits adultery.”

10.verse: Jesus’ disciples then said to him, “If that is how it is, it is better not to marry!”

11.verse: “Not everyone can accept this statement,” Jesus said. “Only those whom God helps.

12.verse: Some are born without the ability to marry, and some are disabled by men, and some refuse to marry for the sake of the Kingdom of Heaven. Let anyone who can, accept my statement.”

13.verse: Little children were brought for Jesus to lay his hands on them and pray. But the disciples scolded those who brought them. “Don’t bother him,” they said.

14.verse: But Jesus said, “Let the little children come to me, and don’t prevent them. For of such is the Kingdom of Heaven.”

15.verse: And he put his hands on their heads and blessed them before he left.

16.verse: Someone came to Jesus with this question: “Good master, what must I do to have eternal life?”

17.verse: “When you call me good you are calling me God,” Jesus replied, “for God alone is truly good. But to answer your question, you can get to heaven if you keep the commandments.”

18.verse: “Which ones?” the man asked. And Jesus replied, “Don’t kill, don’t commit adultery, don’t steal, don’t lie,

19.verse: honor your father and mother, and love your neighbor as yourself!”

20.verse: “I’ve always obeyed every one of them,” the youth replied. “What else must I do?”

21.verse: Jesus told him, “If you want to be perfect, go and sell everything you have and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.”

22.verse: But when the young man heard this, he went away sadly, for he was very rich.

23.verse: Then Jesus said to his disciples, “It is almost impossible for a rich man to get into the Kingdom of Heaven.

24.verse: I say it again—it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God!”

25.verse: This remark confounded the disciples. “Then who in the world can be saved?” they asked.

26.verse: Jesus looked at them intently and said, “Humanly speaking, no one. But with God, everything is possible.”

27.verse: Then Peter said to him, “We left everything to follow you. What will we get out of it?”

28.verse: And Jesus replied, “When I, the Messiah, shall sit upon my glorious throne in the Kingdom,* you my disciples shall certainly sit on twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

29.verse: And anyone who gives up his home, brothers, sisters, father, mother, wife, children, or property, to follow me, shall receive a hundred times as much in return, and shall have eternal life.

30.verse: But many who are first now will be last then; and some who are last now will be first then.”

1.verse: Here is another illustration of the Kingdom of Heaven. “The owner of an estate went out early one morning to hire workers for his harvest field.

2.verse: He agreed to pay them $20 a day and sent them out to work.

3.verse: “A couple of hours later he was passing a hiring hall and saw some men standing around waiting for jobs,

4.verse: so he sent them also into his fields, telling them he would pay them whatever was right at the end of the day.

5.verse: At noon and again around three o’clock in the afternoon he did the same thing.

6.verse: “At five o’clock that evening he was in town again and saw some more men standing around and asked them, ‘Why haven’t you been working today?’

7.verse: “‘Because no one hired us,’ they replied. “‘Then go on out and join the others in my fields,’ he told them.

8.verse: “That evening he told the paymaster to call the men in and pay them, beginning with the last men first.

9.verse: When the men hired at five o’clock were paid, each received $20.

10.verse: So when the men hired earlier came to get theirs, they assumed they would receive much more. But they, too, were paid $20.

11.verse: “They protested, ‘Those fellows worked only one hour, and yet you’ve paid them just as much as those of us who worked all day in the scorching heat.’

12.verse: “They protested, ‘Those fellows worked only one hour, and yet you’ve paid them just as much as those of us who worked all day in the scorching heat.’

13.verse: “‘Friend,’ he answered one of them, ‘I did you no wrong! Didn’t you agree to work all day for $20?

14.verse: Take it and go. It is my desire to pay all the same;

15.verse: is it against the law to give away my money if I want to? Should you be angry because I am kind?’

16.verse: And so it is that the last shall be first, and the first, last.”

17.verse: As Jesus was on the way to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside

18.verse: and talked to them about what would happen to him when they arrived. “I will be betrayed to the chief priests and other Jewish leaders, and they will condemn me to die.

19.verse: And they will hand me over to the Roman government, and I will be mocked and crucified, and the third day I will rise to life again.”

20.verse: Then the mother of James and John, the sons of Zebedee, brought them to Jesus and respectfully asked a favor.

21.verse: “What is your request?” he asked. She replied, “In your Kingdom, will you let my two sons sit on two thrones next to yours?”

22.verse: But Jesus told her, “You don’t know what you are asking!” Then he turned to James and John and asked them, “Are you able to drink from the terrible cup I am about to drink from?” “Yes,” they replied, “we are able!”

23.verse: “You shall indeed drink from it,” he told them. “But I have no right to say who will sit on the thrones next to mine. Those places are reserved for the persons my Father selects.”

24.verse: The other ten disciples were indignant when they heard what James and John had asked for.

25.verse: But Jesus called them together and said, “Among the heathen, kings are tyrants and each minor official lords it over those beneath him.

26.verse: But among you it is quite different. Anyone wanting to be a leader among you must be your servant.

27.verse: And if you want to be right at the top, you must serve like a slave.

28.verse: Your attitude must be like my own, for I, the Messiah,* did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give my life as a ransom for many.”

29.verse: As Jesus and the disciples left the city of Jericho, a vast crowd surged along behind.

30.verse: Two blind men were sitting beside the road, and when they heard that Jesus was coming that way, they began shouting, “Sir, King David’s Son, have mercy on us!”

31.verse: The crowd told them to be quiet, but they only yelled the louder.

32.verse: When Jesus came to the place where they were, he stopped in the road and called, “What do you want me to do for you?” “Sir,” they said, “we want to see!”

33.verse: When Jesus came to the place where they were, he stopped in the road and called, “What do you want me to do for you?” “Sir,” they said, “we want to see!”

34.verse: Jesus was moved with pity for them and touched their eyes. And instantly they could see, and followed him.

1.verse: As Jesus and the disciples approached Jerusalem, and were near the town of Bethphage on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of them into the village ahead.

2.verse: “Just as you enter,” he said, “you will see a donkey tied there, with its colt beside it. Untie them and bring them here.

3.verse: If anyone asks you what you are doing, just say, ‘The Master needs them,’ and there will be no trouble.”

4.verse: This was done to fulfill the ancient prophecy,

5.verse: “Tell Jerusalem her King is coming to her, riding humbly on a donkey’s colt!”

6.verse: The two disciples did as Jesus said,

7.verse: and brought the animals to him and threw their garments over the colt for him to ride on.

8.verse: And some in the crowd threw down their coats along the road ahead of him, and others cut branches from the trees and spread them out before him.

9.verse: Then the crowds surged on ahead and pressed along behind, shouting, “God bless King David’s Son!” . . . “God’s Man is here!” . . . “Bless him, Lord!” . . . “Praise God in highest heaven!”

10.verse: The entire city of Jerusalem was stirred as he entered. “Who is this?” they asked.

11.verse: And the crowds replied, “It’s Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth up in Galilee.”

12.verse: Jesus went into the Temple, drove out the merchants, and knocked over the money changers’ tables and the stalls of those selling doves.

13.verse: “The Scriptures say my Temple is a place of prayer,” he declared, “but you have turned it into a den of thieves.”

14.verse: And now the blind and crippled came to him, and he healed them there in the Temple.

15.verse: But when the chief priests and other Jewish leaders saw these wonderful miracles and heard even the little children in the Temple shouting, “God bless the Son of David,” they were disturbed and indignant and asked him, “Do you hear what these children are saying?”

16.verse: “Yes,” Jesus replied. “Didn’t you ever read the Scriptures? For they say, ‘Even little babies shall praise him!’”

17.verse: Then he returned to Bethany, where he stayed overnight.

18.verse: In the morning, as he was returning to Jerusalem, he was hungry

19.verse: and noticed a fig tree beside the road. He went over to see if there were any figs, but there were only leaves. Then he said to it, “Never bear fruit again!” And soon the fig tree withered up.

20.verse: The disciples were utterly amazed and asked, “How did the fig tree wither so quickly?”

21.verse: Then Jesus told them, “Truly, if you have faith and don’t doubt, you can do things like this and much more. You can even say to this Mount of Olives, ‘Move over into the ocean,’ and it will.

22.verse: You can get anything—anything you ask for in prayer—if you believe.”

23.verse: When he had returned to the Temple and was teaching, the chief priests and other Jewish leaders came up to him and demanded to know by whose authority he had thrown out the merchants the day before.

24.verse: “I’ll tell you if you answer one question first,” Jesus replied.

25.verse: “Was John the Baptist sent from God or not?” They talked it over among themselves. “If we say, ‘From God,’” they said, “then he will ask why we didn’t believe what John said.

26.verse: And if we deny that God sent him, we’ll be mobbed, for the crowd all think he was a prophet.”

27.verse: So they finally replied, “We don’t know!” And Jesus said, “Then I won’t answer your question either.

28.verse: “But what do you think about this? A man with two sons told the older boy, ‘Son, go out and work on the farm today.’

29.verse: ‘I won’t,’ he answered, but later he changed his mind and went.

30.verse: Then the father told the youngest, ‘You go!’ and he said, ‘Yes, sir, I will.’ But he didn’t.

31.verse: Which of the two was obeying his father?” They replied, “The first, of course.” Then Jesus explained his meaning: “Surely evil men and prostitutes will get into the Kingdom before you do.

32.verse: For John the Baptist told you to repent and turn to God, and you wouldn’t, while very evil men and prostitutes did. And even when you saw this happening, you refused to repent, and so you couldn’t believe.

33.verse: “Now listen to this story: A certain landowner planted a vineyard with a hedge around it, and built a platform for the watchman, then leased the vineyard to some farmers on a sharecrop basis, and went away to live in another country.

34.verse: “At the time of the grape harvest he sent his agents to the farmers to collect his share.

35.verse: But the farmers attacked his men, beat one, killed one, and stoned another.

36.verse: “Then he sent a larger group of his men to collect for him, but the results were the same.

37.verse: Finally the owner sent his son, thinking they would surely respect him.

38.verse: “But when these farmers saw the son coming, they said among themselves, ‘Here comes the heir to this estate; come on, let’s kill him and get it for ourselves!’

39.verse: So they dragged him out of the vineyard and killed him.

40.verse: “When the owner returns, what do you think he will do to those farmers?”

41.verse: The Jewish leaders replied, “He will put the wicked men to a horrible death and lease the vineyard to others who will pay him promptly.”

42.verse: Then Jesus asked them, “Didn’t you ever read in the Scriptures: ‘The stone rejected by the builders has been made the honored cornerstone; how remarkable! what an amazing thing the Lord has done’?

43.verse: “What I mean is that the Kingdom of God shall be taken away from you, and given to a nation that will give God his share of the crop.

44.verse: All who stumble on this rock of truth shall be broken, but those it falls on will be scattered as dust.”

45.verse: When the chief priests and other Jewish leaders realized that Jesus was talking about them—that they were the farmers in his story—

46.verse: they wanted to get rid of him but were afraid to try because of the crowds, for they accepted Jesus as a prophet.

1.verse: Jesus told several other stories to show what the Kingdom of Heaven is like. “For instance,” he said, “it can be illustrated by the story of a king who prepared a great wedding dinner for his son.

2.verse: Jesus told several other stories to show what the Kingdom of Heaven is like. “For instance,” he said, “it can be illustrated by the story of a king who prepared a great wedding dinner for his son.

3.verse: Many guests were invited, and when the banquet was ready, he sent messengers to notify everyone that it was time to come. But all refused!

4.verse: So he sent other servants to tell them, ‘Everything is ready and the roast is in the oven. Hurry!’

5.verse: “But the guests he had invited merely laughed and went on about their business, one to his farm, another to his store;

6.verse: others beat up his messengers and treated them shamefully, even killing some of them.

7.verse: “Then the angry king sent out his army and destroyed the murderers and burned their city.

8.verse: And he said to his servants, ‘The wedding feast is ready, and the guests I invited aren’t worthy of the honor.

9.verse: Now go out to the street corners and invite everyone you see.’

10.verse: “So the servants did, and brought in all they could find, good and bad alike; and the banquet hall was filled with guests.

11.verse: But when the king came in to meet the guests, he noticed a man who wasn’t wearing the wedding robe provided for him.

12.verse: “‘Friend,’ he asked, ‘how does it happen that you are here without a wedding robe?’ And the man had no reply.

13.verse: “Then the king said to his aides, ‘Bind him hand and foot and throw him out into the outer darkness where there is weeping and gnashing of teeth.’

14.verse: For many are called, but few are chosen.”

15.verse: Then the Pharisees met together to try to think of some way to trap Jesus into saying something for which they could arrest him.

16.verse: They decided to send some of their men along with the Herodians to ask him this question: “Sir, we know you are very honest and teach the truth regardless of the consequences, without fear or favor.

17.verse: Now tell us, is it right to pay taxes to the Roman government or not?”

18.verse: But Jesus saw what they were after. “You hypocrites!” he exclaimed. “Who are you trying to fool with your trick questions?

19.verse: Here, show me a coin.” And they handed him a penny.

20.verse: “Whose picture is stamped on it?” he asked them. “And whose name is this beneath the picture?”

21.verse: “Caesar’s,” they replied. “Well, then,” he said, “give it to Caesar if it is his, and give God everything that belongs to God.”

22.verse: His reply surprised and baffled them, and they went away.

23.verse: But that same day some of the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection after death, came to him and asked,

24.verse: “Sir, Moses said that if a man died without children, his brother should marry the widow and their children would get all the dead man’s property.

25.verse: Well, we had among us a family of seven brothers. The first of these men married and then died, without children, so his widow became the second brother’s wife.

26.verse: This brother also died without children, and the wife was passed to the next brother, and so on until she had been the wife of each of them.

27.verse: And then she also died.

28.verse: So whose wife will she be in the resurrection? For she was the wife of all seven of them!”

29.verse: But Jesus said, “Your error is caused by your ignorance of the Scriptures and of God’s power!

30.verse: For in the resurrection there is no marriage; everyone is as the angels in heaven.

31.verse: But now, as to whether there is a resurrection of the dead—don’t you ever read the Scriptures? Don’t you realize that God was speaking directly to you when he said,

32.verse: ‘I am the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob’? So God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.”

33.verse: The crowds were profoundly impressed by his answers—

34.verse: but not the Pharisees! When they heard that he had routed the Sadducees with his reply, they thought up a fresh question of their own to ask him. One of them, a lawyer, spoke up:

35.verse: but not the Pharisees! When they heard that he had routed the Sadducees with his reply, they thought up a fresh question of their own to ask him. One of them, a lawyer, spoke up:

36.verse: “Sir, which is the most important command in the laws of Moses?”

37.verse: Jesus replied, “‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, and mind.’

38.verse: This is the first and greatest commandment. The second most important is similar: ‘Love your neighbor as much as you love yourself.’

39.verse: This is the first and greatest commandment. The second most important is similar: ‘Love your neighbor as much as you love yourself.’

40.verse: All the other commandments and all the demands of the prophets stem from these two laws and are fulfilled if you obey them. Keep only these and you will find that you are obeying all the others.”

41.verse: Then, surrounded by the Pharisees, he asked them a question:

42.verse: “What about the Messiah? Whose son is he?” “The son of David,” they replied.

43.verse: “Then why does David, speaking under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, call him ‘Lord’?” Jesus asked. “For David said,

44.verse: ‘God said to my Lord, Sit at my right hand until I put your enemies beneath your feet.’

45.verse: Since David called him ‘Lord,’ how can he be merely his son?”

46.verse: They had no answer. And after that no one dared ask him any more questions.

1.verse: Then Jesus said to the crowds, and to his disciples,

2.verse: “You would think these Jewish leaders and these Pharisees were Moses, the way they keep making up so many laws!

3.verse: And of course you should obey their every whim! It may be all right to do what they say, but above anything else, don’t follow their example. For they don’t do what they tell you to do.

4.verse: They load you with impossible demands that they themselves don’t even try to keep.

5.verse: “Everything they do is done for show. They act holy by wearing on their arms little prayer boxes with Scripture verses inside,* and by lengthening the memorial fringes of their robes.

6.verse: And how they love to sit at the head table at banquets and in the reserved pews in the synagogue!

7.verse: How they enjoy the deference paid them on the streets and to be called ‘Rabbi’ and ‘Master’!

8.verse: Don’t ever let anyone call you that. For only God is your Rabbi and all of you are on the same level, as brothers.

9.verse: And don’t address anyone here on earth as ‘Father,’ for only God in heaven should be addressed like that.

10.verse: And don’t be called ‘Master,’ for only one is your master, even the Messiah.

11.verse: “The more lowly your service to others, the greater you are. To be the greatest, be a servant.

12.verse: But those who think themselves great shall be disappointed and humbled; and those who humble themselves shall be exalted.

13.verse: “Woe to you, Pharisees, and you other religious leaders. Hypocrites! For you won’t let others enter the Kingdom of Heaven and won’t go in yourselves. And you pretend to be holy, with all your long, public prayers in the streets, while you are evicting widows from their homes. Hypocrites!

14.verse: “Woe to you, Pharisees, and you other religious leaders. Hypocrites! For you won’t let others enter the Kingdom of Heaven and won’t go in yourselves. And you pretend to be holy, with all your long, public prayers in the streets, while you are evicting widows from their homes. Hypocrites!

15.verse: Yes, woe upon you hypocrites. For you go to all lengths to make one convert, and then turn him into twice the son of hell you are yourselves.

16.verse: Blind guides! Woe upon you! For your rule is that to swear ‘By God’s Temple’ means nothing—you can break that oath, but to swear ‘By the gold in the Temple’ is binding!

17.verse: Blind fools! Which is greater, the gold, or the Temple that sanctifies the gold?

18.verse: And you say that to take an oath ‘By the altar’ can be broken, but to swear ‘By the gifts on the altar’ is binding!

19.verse: Blind! For which is greater, the gift on the altar, or the altar itself that sanctifies the gift?

20.verse: When you swear ‘By the altar,’ you are swearing by it and everything on it,

21.verse: and when you swear ‘By the Temple,’ you are swearing by it and by God who lives in it.

22.verse: And when you swear ‘By heavens,’ you are swearing by the Throne of God and by God himself.

23.verse: “Yes, woe upon you, Pharisees, and you other religious leaders—hypocrites! For you tithe down to the last mint leaf in your garden, but ignore the important things—justice and mercy and faith. Yes, you should tithe, but you shouldn’t leave the more important things undone.

24.verse: Blind guides! You strain out a gnat and swallow a camel.

25.verse: “Woe to you, Pharisees, and you religious leaders—hypocrites! You are so careful to polish the outside of the cup, but the inside is foul with extortion and greed.

26.verse: Blind Pharisees! First cleanse the inside of the cup, and then the whole cup will be clean.

27.verse: “Woe to you, Pharisees, and you religious leaders! You are like beautiful mausoleums—full of dead men’s bones, and of foulness and corruption.

28.verse: You try to look like saintly men, but underneath those pious robes of yours are hearts besmirched with every sort of hypocrisy and sin.

29.verse: “Yes, woe to you, Pharisees, and you religious leaders—hypocrites! For you build monuments to the prophets killed by your fathers and lay flowers on the graves of the godly men they destroyed, and say, ‘We certainly would never have acted as our fathers did.’

30.verse: “Yes, woe to you, Pharisees, and you religious leaders—hypocrites! For you build monuments to the prophets killed by your fathers and lay flowers on the graves of the godly men they destroyed, and say, ‘We certainly would never have acted as our fathers did.’

31.verse: “In saying that, you are accusing yourselves of being the sons of wicked men.

32.verse: And you are following in their steps, filling up the full measure of their evil.

33.verse: Snakes! Sons of vipers! How shall you escape the judgment of hell?

34.verse: “I will send you prophets, and wise men, and inspired writers, and you will kill some by crucifixion, and rip open the backs of others with whips in your synagogues, and hound them from city to city,

35.verse: so that you will become guilty of all the blood of murdered godly men from righteous Abel to Zechariah (son of Barachiah), slain by you in the Temple between the altar and the sanctuary.

36.verse: Yes, all the accumulated judgment of the centuries shall break upon the heads of this very generation.

37.verse: “O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones all those God sends to her! How often I have wanted to gather your children together as a hen gathers her chicks beneath her wings, but you wouldn’t let me.

38.verse: And now your house is left to you, desolate.

39.verse: For I tell you this, you will never see me again until you are ready to welcome the one sent to you from God.”

1.verse: As Jesus was leaving the Temple grounds, his disciples came along and wanted to take him on a tour of the various Temple buildings.

2.verse: But he told them, “All these buildings will be knocked down, with not one stone left on top of another!”

3.verse: “When will this happen?” the disciples asked him later, as he sat on the slopes of the Mount of Olives. “What events will signal your return and the end of the world?”

4.verse: Jesus told them, “Don’t let anyone fool you.

5.verse: For many will come claiming to be the Messiah and will lead many astray.

6.verse: When you hear of wars beginning, this does not signal my return; these must come, but the end is not yet.

7.verse: The nations and kingdoms of the earth will rise against each other, and there will be famines and earthquakes in many places.

8.verse: But all this will be only the beginning of the horrors to come.

9.verse: “Then you will be tortured and killed and hated all over the world because you are mine,

10.verse: and many of you shall fall back into sin and betray and hate each other.

11.verse: And many false prophets will appear and lead many astray.

12.verse: Sin will be rampant everywhere and will cool the love of many.

13.verse: But those enduring to the end shall be saved.

14.verse: “And the Good News about the Kingdom will be preached throughout the whole world, so that all nations will hear it, and then, finally, the end will come.

15.verse: “So, when you see the horrible thing (told about by Daniel* the prophet) standing in a holy place (Note to the reader: You know what is meant!*),

16.verse: then those in Judea must flee into the Judean hills.

17.verse: Those on their porches must not even go inside to pack before they flee.

18.verse: Those in the fields should not return to their homes for their clothes.

19.verse: “And woe to pregnant women and to those with babies in those days.

20.verse: And pray that your flight will not be in winter, or on the Sabbath.

21.verse: For there will be persecution such as the world has never before seen in all its history and will never see again.

22.verse: “In fact, unless those days are shortened, all mankind will perish. But they will be shortened for the sake of God’s chosen people.

23.verse: “Then if anyone tells you, ‘The Messiah has arrived at such and such a place, or has appeared here or there,’ don’t believe it.

24.verse: For false Christs shall arise, and false prophets, and will do wonderful miracles so that if it were possible, even God’s chosen ones would be deceived.

25.verse: See, I have warned you.

26.verse: “So if someone tells you the Messiah has returned and is out in the desert, don’t bother to go and look. Or, that he is hiding at a certain place, don’t believe it!

27.verse: For as the lightning flashes across the sky from east to west, so shall my coming be, when I, the Messiah, return.

28.verse: And wherever the carcass is, there the vultures will gather.

29.verse: “Immediately after the persecution of those days the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give light, and the stars will seem to fall from the heavens, and the powers overshadowing the earth will be convulsed.*

30.verse: “And then at last the signal of my coming will appear in the heavens, and there will be deep mourning all around the earth. And the nations of the world will see me arrive in the clouds of heaven, with power and great glory.

31.verse: And I shall send forth my angels with the sound of a mighty trumpet blast, and they shall gather my chosen ones from the farthest ends of the earth and heaven.

32.verse: “Now learn a lesson from the fig tree. When her branch is tender and the leaves begin to sprout, you know that summer is almost here.

33.verse: Just so, when you see all these things beginning to happen, you can know that my return is near, even at the doors.

34.verse: Then at last this age will come to its close.

35.verse: “Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words remain forever.

36.verse: But no one knows the date and hour when the end will be—not even the angels. No, nor even God’s Son. Only the Father knows.

37.verse: “The world will be at ease—banquets and parties and weddings—just as it was in Noah’s time before the sudden coming of the Flood;

38.verse: “The world will be at ease—banquets and parties and weddings—just as it was in Noah’s time before the sudden coming of the Flood;

39.verse: people wouldn’t believe what was going to happen until the Flood actually arrived and took them all away. So shall my coming be.

40.verse: “Two men will be working together in the fields, and one will be taken, the other left.

41.verse: Two women will be going about their household tasks; one will be taken, the other left.

42.verse: “So be prepared, for you don’t know what day your Lord is coming.

43.verse: “Just as a man can prevent trouble from thieves by keeping watch for them,

44.verse: so you can avoid trouble by always being ready for my unannounced return.

45.verse: “Are you a wise and faithful servant of the Lord? Have I given you the task of managing my household, to feed my children day by day?

46.verse: Blessings on you if I return and find you faithfully doing your work.

47.verse: I will put such faithful ones in charge of everything I own!

48.verse: “But if you are evil and say to yourself, ‘My Lord won’t be coming for a while,’

49.verse: and begin oppressing your fellow servants, partying and getting drunk,

50.verse: your Lord will arrive unannounced and unexpected,

51.verse: and severely whip you and send you off to the judgment of the hypocrites; there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

1.verse: “The Kingdom of Heaven can be illustrated by the story of ten bridesmaids who took their lamps and went to meet the bridegroom.

2.verse: But only five of them were wise enough to fill their lamps with oil, while the other five were foolish and forgot.

3.verse: But only five of them were wise enough to fill their lamps with oil, while the other five were foolish and forgot.

4.verse: But only five of them were wise enough to fill their lamps with oil, while the other five were foolish and forgot.

5.verse: “So, when the bridegroom was delayed, they lay down to rest until midnight, when they were roused by the shout, ‘The bridegroom is coming! Come out and welcome him!’

6.verse: “So, when the bridegroom was delayed, they lay down to rest until midnight, when they were roused by the shout, ‘The bridegroom is coming! Come out and welcome him!’

7.verse: “All the girls jumped up and trimmed their lamps. Then the five who hadn’t any oil begged the others to share with them, for their lamps were going out.

8.verse: “All the girls jumped up and trimmed their lamps. Then the five who hadn’t any oil begged the others to share with them, for their lamps were going out.

9.verse: “But the others replied, ‘We haven’t enough. Go instead to the shops and buy some for yourselves.’

10.verse: “But while they were gone, the bridegroom came, and those who were ready went in with him to the marriage feast, and the door was locked.

11.verse: “Later, when the other five returned, they stood outside, calling, ‘Sir, open the door for us!’

12.verse: “But he called back, ‘Go away! It is too late!’

13.verse: “So stay awake and be prepared, for you do not know the date or moment of my return.

14.verse: “Again, the Kingdom of Heaven can be illustrated by the story of a man going into another country, who called together his servants and loaned them money to invest for him while he was gone.

15.verse: “He gave $5,000 to one, $2,000 to another, and $1,000 to the last—dividing it in proportion to their abilities—and then left on his trip.

16.verse: The man who received the $5,000 began immediately to buy and sell with it and soon earned another $5,000.

17.verse: The man with $2,000 went right to work, too, and earned another $2,000.

18.verse: “But the man who received the $1,000 dug a hole in the ground and hid the money for safekeeping.

19.verse: “After a long time their master returned from his trip and called them to him to account for his money.

20.verse: The man to whom he had entrusted the $5,000 brought him $10,000.

21.verse: “His master praised him for good work. ‘You have been faithful in handling this small amount,’ he told him, ‘so now I will give you many more responsibilities. Begin the joyous tasks I have assigned to you.’

22.verse: “Next came the man who had received the $2,000, with the report, ‘Sir, you gave me $2,000 to use, and I have doubled it.’

23.verse: “‘Good work,’ his master said. ‘You are a good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over this small amount, so now I will give you much more.’

24.verse: “Then the man with the $1,000 came and said, ‘Sir, I knew you were a hard man, and I was afraid you would rob me of what I earned, so I hid your money in the earth and here it is!’

25.verse: “Then the man with the $1,000 came and said, ‘Sir, I knew you were a hard man, and I was afraid you would rob me of what I earned, so I hid your money in the earth and here it is!’

26.verse: “But his master replied, ‘Wicked man! Lazy slave! Since you knew I would demand your profit,

27.verse: you should at least have put my money into the bank so I could have some interest.

28.verse: Take the money from this man and give it to the man with the $10,000.

29.verse: For the man who uses well what he is given shall be given more, and he shall have abundance. But from the man who is unfaithful, even what little responsibility he has shall be taken from him.

30.verse: And throw the useless servant out into outer darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’

31.verse: “But when I, the Messiah, shall come in my glory, and all the angels with me, then I shall sit upon my throne of glory.

32.verse: And all the nations shall be gathered before me. And I will separate the people as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats,

33.verse: and place the sheep at my right hand, and the goats at my left.

34.verse: “Then I, the King, shall say to those at my right, ‘Come, blessed of my Father, into the Kingdom prepared for you from the founding of the world.

35.verse: For I was hungry and you fed me; I was thirsty and you gave me water; I was a stranger and you invited me into your homes;

36.verse: naked and you clothed me; sick and in prison, and you visited me.’

37.verse: “Then these righteous ones will reply, ‘Sir, when did we ever see you hungry and feed you? Or thirsty and give you anything to drink?

38.verse: Or a stranger, and help you? Or naked, and clothe you?

39.verse: When did we ever see you sick or in prison, and visit you?’

40.verse: “And I, the King, will tell them, ‘When you did it to these my brothers, you were doing it to me!’

41.verse: Then I will turn to those on my left and say, ‘Away with you, you cursed ones, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his demons.

42.verse: For I was hungry and you wouldn’t feed me; thirsty, and you wouldn’t give me anything to drink;

43.verse: a stranger, and you refused me hospitality; naked, and you wouldn’t clothe me; sick, and in prison, and you didn’t visit me.’

44.verse: “Then they will reply, ‘Lord, when did we ever see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and not help you?’

45.verse: “And I will answer, ‘When you refused to help the least of these my brothers, you were refusing help to me.’

46.verse: “And they shall go away into eternal punishment; but the righteous into everlasting life.”

1.verse: When Jesus had finished this talk with his disciples, he told them,

2.verse: “As you know, the Passover celebration begins in two days, and I shall be betrayed and crucified.”

3.verse: At that very moment the chief priests and other Jewish officials were meeting at the residence of Caiaphas the high priest,

4.verse: to discuss ways of capturing Jesus quietly and killing him.

5.verse: “But not during the Passover celebration,” they agreed, “for there would be a riot.”

6.verse: Jesus now proceeded to Bethany, to the home of Simon the leper.

7.verse: While he was eating, a woman came in with a bottle of very expensive perfume and poured it over his head.

8.verse: The disciples were indignant. “What a waste of good money,” they said. “Why, she could have sold it for a fortune and given it to the poor.”

9.verse: The disciples were indignant. “What a waste of good money,” they said. “Why, she could have sold it for a fortune and given it to the poor.”

10.verse: Jesus knew what they were thinking and said, “Why are you criticizing her? For she has done a good thing to me.

11.verse: You will always have the poor among you, but you won’t always have me.

12.verse: She has poured this perfume on me to prepare my body for burial.

13.verse: And she will always be remembered for this deed. The story of what she has done will be told throughout the whole world, wherever the Good News is preached.”

14.verse: Then Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve apostles, went to the chief priests

15.verse: and asked, “How much will you pay me to get Jesus into your hands?” And they gave him thirty silver coins.

16.verse: From that time on, Judas watched for an opportunity to betray Jesus to them.

17.verse: On the first day of the Passover ceremonies, when bread made with yeast was purged from every Jewish home, the disciples came to Jesus and asked, “Where shall we plan to eat the Passover?”

18.verse: He replied, “Go into the city and see Mr. So-and-So, and tell him, ‘Our Master says, my time has come, and I will eat the Passover meal with my disciples at your house.’”

19.verse: So the disciples did as he told them and prepared the supper there.

20.verse: That evening as he sat eating with the Twelve, he said, “One of you will betray me.”

21.verse: That evening as he sat eating with the Twelve, he said, “One of you will betray me.”

22.verse: Sorrow chilled their hearts, and each one asked, “Am I the one?”

23.verse: He replied, “It is the one I served first.

24.verse: For I must die just as was prophesied, but woe to the man by whom I am betrayed. Far better for that one if he had never been born.”

25.verse: Judas, too, had asked him, “Rabbi, am I the one?” And Jesus had told him, “Yes.”

26.verse: As they were eating, Jesus took a small loaf of bread and blessed it and broke it apart and gave it to the disciples and said, “Take it and eat it, for this is my body.”

27.verse: And he took a cup of wine and gave thanks for it and gave it to them and said, “Each one drink from it,

28.verse: for this is my blood, sealing the new covenant. It is poured out to forgive the sins of multitudes.

29.verse: Mark my words—I will not drink this wine again until the day I drink it new with you in my Father’s Kingdom.”

30.verse: And when they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.

31.verse: Then Jesus said to them, “Tonight you will all desert me. For it is written in the Scriptures that God will smite the Shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.

32.verse: But after I have been brought back to life again, I will go to Galilee and meet you there.”

33.verse: Peter declared, “If everyone else deserts you, I won’t.”

34.verse: Jesus told him, “The truth is that this very night, before the cock crows at dawn, you will deny me three times!”

35.verse: “I would die first!” Peter insisted. And all the other disciples said the same thing.

36.verse: Then Jesus brought them to a garden grove, Gethsemane, and told them to sit down and wait while he went on ahead to pray.

37.verse: He took Peter with him and Zebedee’s two sons James and John, and began to be filled with anguish and despair.

38.verse: Then he told them, “My soul is crushed with horror and sadness to the point of death . . . stay here . . . stay awake with me.”

39.verse: He went forward a little, and fell face downward on the ground, and prayed, “My Father! If it is possible, let this cup be taken away from me. But I want your will, not mine.”

40.verse: Then he returned to the three disciples and found them asleep. “Peter,” he called, “couldn’t you even stay awake with me one hour?

41.verse: Keep alert and pray. Otherwise temptation will overpower you. For the spirit indeed is willing, but how weak the body is!”

42.verse: Again he left them and prayed, “My Father! If this cup cannot go away until I drink it all, your will be done.”

43.verse: He returned to them again and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy,

44.verse: so he went back to prayer the third time, saying the same things again.

45.verse: Then he came to the disciples and said, “Sleep on now and take your rest . . . but no! The time has come! I am betrayed into the hands of evil men!

46.verse: Up! Let’s be going! Look! Here comes the man who is betraying me!”

47.verse: At that very moment while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived with a great crowd armed with swords and clubs, sent by the Jewish leaders.

48.verse: Judas had told them to arrest the man he greeted, for that would be the one they were after.

49.verse: So now Judas came straight to Jesus and said, “Hello, Master!” and embraced him in friendly fashion.

50.verse: Jesus said, “My friend, go ahead and do what you have come for.” Then the others grabbed him.

51.verse: One of the men with Jesus pulled out a sword and slashed off the ear of the high priest’s servant.

52.verse: “Put away your sword,” Jesus told him. “Those using swords will get killed.

53.verse: Don’t you realize that I could ask my Father for thousands of angels to protect us, and he would send them instantly?

54.verse: But if I did, how would the Scriptures be fulfilled that describe what is happening now?”

55.verse: Then Jesus spoke to the crowd. “Am I some dangerous criminal,” he asked, “that you had to arm yourselves with swords and clubs before you could arrest me? I was with you teaching daily in the Temple and you didn’t stop me then.

56.verse: But this is all happening to fulfill the words of the prophets as recorded in the Scriptures.” At that point, all the disciples deserted him and fled.

57.verse: Then the mob led him to the home of Caiaphas, the high priest, where all the Jewish leaders were gathering.

58.verse: Meanwhile, Peter was following far to the rear, and came to the courtyard of the high priest’s house and went in and sat with the soldiers, and waited to see what was going to be done to Jesus.

59.verse: The chief priests and, in fact, the entire Jewish Supreme Court assembled there and looked for witnesses who would lie about Jesus, in order to build a case against him that would result in a death sentence.

60.verse: But even though they found many who agreed to be false witnesses, these always contradicted each other. Finally two men were found who declared, “This man said, ‘I am able to destroy the Temple of God and rebuild it in three days.’”

61.verse: But even though they found many who agreed to be false witnesses, these always contradicted each other. Finally two men were found who declared, “This man said, ‘I am able to destroy the Temple of God and rebuild it in three days.’”

62.verse: Then the high priest stood up and said to Jesus, “Well, what about it? Did you say that, or didn’t you?”

63.verse: But Jesus remained silent. Then the high priest said to him, “I demand in the name of the living God that you tell us whether you claim to be the Messiah, the Son of God.”

64.verse: “Yes,” Jesus said, “I am. And in the future you will see me, the Messiah, sitting at the right hand of God and returning on the clouds of heaven.”

65.verse: Then the high priest tore at his own clothing, shouting, “Blasphemy! What need have we for other witnesses? You have all heard him say it! What is your verdict?” They shouted, “Death!—Death!—Death!”

66.verse: Then the high priest tore at his own clothing, shouting, “Blasphemy! What need have we for other witnesses? You have all heard him say it! What is your verdict?” They shouted, “Death!—Death!—Death!”

67.verse: Then they spat in his face and struck him and some slapped him,

68.verse: saying, “Prophesy to us, you Messiah! Who struck you that time?”

69.verse: Meanwhile, as Peter was sitting in the courtyard, a girl came over and said to him, “You were with Jesus, for both of you are from Galilee.”

70.verse: But Peter denied it loudly. “I don’t even know what you are talking about,” he angrily declared.

71.verse: Later, out by the gate, another girl noticed him and said to those standing around, “This man was with Jesus—from Nazareth.”

72.verse: Again Peter denied it, this time with an oath. “I don’t even know the man,” he said.

73.verse: But after a while the men who had been standing there came over to him and said, “We know you are one of his disciples, for we can tell by your Galilean accent.”

74.verse: Peter began to curse and swear. “I don’t even know the man,” he said. And immediately the cock crowed.

75.verse: Then Peter remembered what Jesus had said, “Before the cock crows, you will deny me three times.” And he went away, crying bitterly.

1.verse: When it was morning, the chief priests and Jewish leaders met again to discuss how to induce the Roman government to sentence Jesus to death.

2.verse: Then they sent him in chains to Pilate, the Roman governor.

3.verse: About that time Judas, who betrayed him, when he saw that Jesus had been condemned to die, changed his mind and deeply regretted what he had done, and brought back the money to the chief priests and other Jewish leaders.

4.verse: “I have sinned,” he declared, “for I have betrayed an innocent man.” “That’s your problem,” they retorted.

5.verse: Then he threw the money onto the floor of the Temple and went out and hanged himself.

6.verse: The chief priests picked the money up. “We can’t put it in the collection,” they said, “since it’s against our laws to accept money paid for murder.”

7.verse: They talked it over and finally decided to buy a certain field where the clay was used by potters, and to make it into a cemetery for foreigners who died in Jerusalem.

8.verse: That is why the cemetery is still called “The Field of Blood.”

9.verse: This fulfilled the prophecy of Jeremiah which says, “They took the thirty pieces of silver—the price at which he was valued by the people of Israel—

10.verse: and purchased a field from the potters as the Lord directed me.”

11.verse: Now Jesus was standing before Pilate, the Roman governor. “Are you the Jews’ Messiah?” the governor asked him. “Yes,” Jesus replied.

12.verse: But when the chief priests and other Jewish leaders made their many accusations against him, Jesus remained silent.

13.verse: “Don’t you hear what they are saying?” Pilate demanded.

14.verse: But Jesus said nothing, much to the governor’s surprise.

15.verse: Now the governor’s custom was to release one Jewish prisoner each year during the Passover celebration—anyone they wanted.

16.verse: This year there was a particularly notorious criminal in jail named Barabbas,

17.verse: and as the crowds gathered before Pilate’s house that morning he asked them, “Which shall I release to you—Barabbas, or Jesus your Messiah?”

18.verse: For he knew very well that the Jewish leaders had arrested Jesus out of envy because of his popularity with the people.

19.verse: Just then, as he was presiding over the court, Pilate’s wife sent him this message: “Leave that good man alone; for I had a terrible nightmare concerning him last night.”

20.verse: Meanwhile the chief priests and Jewish officials persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas’s release, and for Jesus’ death.

21.verse: So when the governor asked again, “Which of these two shall I release to you?” the crowd shouted back their reply: “Barabbas!”

22.verse: “Then what shall I do with Jesus, your Messiah?” Pilate asked. And they shouted, “Crucify him!”

23.verse: “Why?” Pilate demanded. “What has he done wrong?” But they kept shouting, “Crucify! Crucify!”

24.verse: When Pilate saw that he wasn’t getting anywhere and that a riot was developing, he sent for a bowl of water and washed his hands before the crowd, saying, “I am innocent of the blood of this good man. The responsibility is yours!”

25.verse: And the mob yelled back, “His blood be on us and on our children!”

26.verse: Then Pilate released Barabbas to them. And after he had whipped Jesus, he gave him to the Roman soldiers to be taken away and crucified.

27.verse: But first they took him into the armory and called out the entire contingent.

28.verse: They stripped him and put a scarlet robe on him,

29.verse: and made a crown from long thorns and put it on his head, and placed a stick in his right hand as a scepter and knelt before him in mockery. “Hail, King of the Jews,” they yelled.

30.verse: And they spat on him and grabbed the stick and beat him on the head with it.

31.verse: After the mockery, they took off the robe and put his own garment on him again, and took him out to crucify him.

32.verse: As they were on the way to the execution grounds they came across a man from Cyrene, in Africa—Simon was his name—and forced him to carry Jesus’ cross.

33.verse: Then they went out to an area known as Golgotha, that is, “Skull Hill,”

34.verse: where the soldiers gave him drugged wine to drink; but when he had tasted it, he refused.

35.verse: After the crucifixion, the soldiers threw dice to divide up his clothes among themselves.

36.verse: Then they sat around and watched him as he hung there.

37.verse: And they put a sign above his head, “This is Jesus, the King of the Jews.”

38.verse: Two robbers were also crucified there that morning, one on either side of him.

39.verse: And the people passing by hurled abuse, shaking their heads at him and saying,

40.verse: “So! You can destroy the Temple and build it again in three days, can you? Well, then, come on down from the cross if you are the Son of God!”

41.verse: And the chief priests and Jewish leaders also mocked him. “He saved others,” they scoffed, “but he can’t save himself! So you are the King of Israel, are you? Come down from the cross and we’ll believe you! He trusted God—let God show his approval by delivering him! Didn’t he say, ‘I am God’s Son’?”

42.verse: And the chief priests and Jewish leaders also mocked him. “He saved others,” they scoffed, “but he can’t save himself! So you are the King of Israel, are you? Come down from the cross and we’ll believe you! He trusted God—let God show his approval by delivering him! Didn’t he say, ‘I am God’s Son’?”

43.verse: And the chief priests and Jewish leaders also mocked him. “He saved others,” they scoffed, “but he can’t save himself! So you are the King of Israel, are you? Come down from the cross and we’ll believe you! He trusted God—let God show his approval by delivering him! Didn’t he say, ‘I am God’s Son’?”

44.verse: And the robbers also threw the same in his teeth.

45.verse: That afternoon, the whole earth was covered with darkness for three hours, from noon until three o’clock.

46.verse: About three o’clock, Jesus shouted, “Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani?” which means, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”

47.verse: Some of the bystanders misunderstood and thought he was calling for Elijah.

48.verse: One of them ran and filled a sponge with sour wine and put it on a stick and held it up to him to drink.

49.verse: But the rest said, “Leave him alone. Let’s see whether Elijah will come and save him.”

50.verse: Then Jesus shouted out again, dismissed his spirit, and died.

51.verse: And look! The curtain secluding the Holiest Place in the Temple was split apart from top to bottom; and the earth shook, and rocks broke,

52.verse: and tombs opened, and many godly men and women who had died came back to life again.

53.verse: After Jesus’ resurrection, they left the cemetery and went into Jerusalem, and appeared to many people there.

54.verse: The soldiers at the crucifixion and their sergeant were terribly frightened by the earthquake and all that happened. They exclaimed, “Surely this was God’s Son.”

55.verse: And many women who had come down from Galilee with Jesus to care for him were watching from a distance.

56.verse: Among them were Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of James and John (the sons of Zebedee).

57.verse: When evening came, a rich man from Arimathea named Joseph, one of Jesus’ followers,

58.verse: went to Pilate and asked for Jesus’ body. And Pilate issued an order to release it to him.

59.verse: Joseph took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,

60.verse: and placed it in his own new rock-hewn tomb, and rolled a great stone across the entrance as he left.

61.verse: Both Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting nearby watching.

62.verse: The next day—at the close of the first day of the Passover ceremonies—the chief priests and Pharisees went to Pilate,

63.verse: and told him, “Sir, that liar once said, ‘After three days I will come back to life again.’

64.verse: So we request an order from you sealing the tomb until the third day, to prevent his disciples from coming and stealing his body and then telling everyone he came back to life! If that happens, we’ll be worse off than we were at first.”

65.verse: “Use your own Temple police,” Pilate told them. “They can guard it safely enough.”

66.verse: So they sealed the stone and posted guards to protect it from intrusion.

1.verse: Early on Sunday morning, as the new day was dawning, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went out to the tomb.

2.verse: Suddenly there was a great earthquake; for an angel of the Lord came down from heaven and rolled aside the stone and sat on it.

3.verse: His face shone like lightning and his clothing was a brilliant white.

4.verse: The guards shook with fear when they saw him, and fell into a dead faint.

5.verse: Then the angel spoke to the women. “Don’t be frightened!” he said. “I know you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified,

6.verse: but he isn’t here! For he has come back to life again, just as he said he would. Come in and see where his body was lying. . . .

7.verse: And now, go quickly and tell his disciples that he has risen from the dead, and that he is going to Galilee to meet them there. That is my message to them.”

8.verse: The women ran from the tomb, badly frightened, but also filled with joy, and rushed to find the disciples to give them the angel’s message.

9.verse: And as they were running, suddenly Jesus was there in front of them! “Good morning!” he said. And they fell to the ground before him, holding his feet and worshiping him.

10.verse: Then Jesus said to them, “Don’t be frightened! Go tell my brothers to leave at once for Galilee, to meet me there.”

11.verse: As the women were on the way into the city, some of the Temple police who had been guarding the tomb went to the chief priests and told them what had happened.

12.verse: A meeting of all the Jewish leaders was called, and it was decided to bribe the police to say they had all been asleep when Jesus’ disciples came during the night and stole his body.

13.verse: A meeting of all the Jewish leaders was called, and it was decided to bribe the police to say they had all been asleep when Jesus’ disciples came during the night and stole his body.

14.verse: “If the governor hears about it,” the Council promised, “we’ll stand up for you and everything will be all right.”

15.verse: So the police accepted the bribe and said what they were told to. Their story spread widely among the Jews and is still believed by them to this very day.

16.verse: Then the eleven disciples left for Galilee, going to the mountain where Jesus had said they would find him.

17.verse: There they met him and worshiped him—but some of them weren’t sure it really was Jesus!

18.verse: He told his disciples, “I have been given all authority in heaven and earth.

19.verse: Therefore go and make disciples in all the nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,

20.verse: and then teach these new disciples to obey all the commands I have given you; and be sure of this—that I am with you always, even to the end of the world.”
